com:
"Cargo cult" means roughly that someone has tried to copy something he has seen, but really does not understand the underlying principle of. And thus, when he makes the copy it wouldn't really work.

In this thread we take examples all over the world when militaries try to emulate something they think is "proper military stuff" and have tried to copy the form, but don't really understand that it wouldn't work. We are not talking about "practicing marching while holding wooden sticks instead of rifles" because that still teaches you how to march.

Picture related is from Ukraine, when Russian occupiers tried to build tank traps as roadblocks, but did so haphazardly from wood.

historical origins: During the WW2, US troops encountered primitive tribes living in pacific islands. These triblas were amazed by the technology and especially "Cargo" - The support material and foodstuffs that the US military had. Cargo came in with flying machines (planes) and seemingly in endless quantities. As US troops left the islands, the locals tried to make a religion out of what they had seen. They copied the arifields and made planes, radio masts and barracks out of wood, hoping they could call "The Cargo" from the heavens once more.

>>56309801
Another thing that signifies the soviet ivestment into this idea are the modifications that followed the ak - they all were focused around automatic fire, like the bigger magazines, recoil compensator and then a muzzle brake, etc. They never really let go of the idea that an "avtomat" is meant to be essentially a long ranged smg rather than its own thing.

The western militaries did no such things. Obviously the STG was abandoned after the fall of the third reich, and everyone just adopted either semi or full auto battle rifles, and used them fairly similarly to how Americans used their Garands which was similar to how everyone used bolt action rifles. The full auto variants were also used similarly to the semi auto ones, except they also adopted the ability to switch to full auto in a pinch or close in, similar to the way STG was able to, however they were much less suited to this role. This was thought of as a fairly niche use and as the wars of the time were largely fought on more open terrain the longer range was thought of as an advantage. Having only one round to produce to go along with your newly adopted general purpose machine gun also helped.

At this point i want to note that both the STG and AK used shortened cartridges with the same caliber as full size rounds, which don't really give massive improvements on ammo weight. Of course, you get the lighter weapon and some 30% improvement in carried ammo wouldn't hurt but unlike the Germany who experimented with both battle rifles and assault rifles and saw lots of trench combat, the countries were reluctant to change their existing eqipment.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56310178
Things really changed with the M16, which used a small caliber high velocity round that outright doubled the ammo capacity, with the light rifle allowing even more while the flat trajectory actually improved the soldier's accuracy at most common combat ranges. This was a tradeoff that was very appealing, especially since by this point armies established their small arms arsenal and the improved manufacturing and logistics allowed an additional small arms round to be much less burdensome to keep. Nobody jumped the gun quite like US and soviet did, who were enamored with the low recoil characteristics of the round due to that idea they had about automatic fire and even had several programs that aimed to improve hit probability in full auto similar to US SPIW program, with AN-94 being the result of one of them. Some countries still keep using battle rifles as their main armament to this day, one example being Greece. More and more countries started adopting the cartridge in the 80s after it became NATO standartized, though, as the benefits were quite real and the round well established.

However, despite the whole classification as an assault rifles, these guns are still used very similarly to the way their predcessors were used before, with the guns designed for the aimed fire, primarily in semi automatic and use of full auto ranges from very rarely to more situational in different countries, but the focus on the rifle being a rifle remains. Even in SPIW program where US studied various burst fire mechanisms to improve hit probability the overall empathis was on limited and aimed bursts that would promote accuracy per round fired rather than reduce it.

During Vietnam, despite being against doctrine, riflemen were all about full auto/spray into the jungle. That ended with the A3 but picked up again for a short time during the beginning of GWOT when the army started replacing M16s with the M4 carbine, Army battle tactics on the ground went back to amassed suppressing fire. This was made more effective with the policy to provide every rifleman an optic. Once things calmed down and urban combat became less frequent you started seeing troops use more deliberate firing.

com:
Previous >>56243906
Slow general edition

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

>>56307268
if you look at knife fights that take place in some of the remaining places with a "knife fighting culture," you will see very careful behavior. the true meta of 1v1 knife fighting is avoiding commitment and picking the other person apart. eventually someone gets their fingers chopped off, or their hand/wrist badly gashed, or they just eat one good quick stab to lung, and their disadvantage snowballs into defeat.

between two retards who are really really mad at each other and just going nuts, or two untrained idiots with markers that are unafraid of death, it's kind of like dogfighting in the era of gun planes: if you fly at each other attacking head on, you both die, or at the very least the winner is left even more heavily to chance.

some people say that it's a dumb game to learn, because even if you're "good", you still might lose to someone "bad." to me that's exactly why it's a useful game to understand, as if you ever were in that situation, you might as well have every advantage you can get. on top of that, as few people even bother to try to understand it, you are much more likely to encounter someone with zero information than someone at your level.

at the same time, because it ultimately lacks reliability, you probably wouldn't want to devote your entire life to becoming a Knifemaster. similarly if you live in the UK and have a weaponized umbrella, it would behoove you to have some understanding/practice/training with it, but don't become Umbrella Man. 1 year of boxing and grappling would probably make you more deadly than 5 years of doing random Umbrella katas and sparring with typical eggheaded autismos that have no physicality in their backgrounds. the same is basically true of using a knife. your body is such a huge part of the weapon that your strength/speed/coordination really outweighs the need for deep knowledge of knife-fu.

>>56304847
Supplying a million troops through a couple captured harbors is harder than supplying 5,000 marines who are going to clear an island and then get back on board to go to the next island.

Because your goals and requirements are more modest you have more flexibility in where you can land; anywhere on the island you can get your boats close enough is good, you aren't dependent on capturing the one harbor equipped for heavy cargo transfer. Because of that, you aren't having to smash your face into the defenses they prepared because they knew where you'd have to go.

Same shit you should be doing anyways, backup power, be it a solar crank gas whatever. Couple weeks food & water with purification options. com:
Paul Harrel once said he shot and killed a deer with .25 ACP, apparently dropped it dead on the spot. That made me wonder: if a .25 ACP can take a deer that easily, .32 ACP would certainly be a capable big game hunting cartridge. With modern smokeless powders you are looking at around 75 grains of lead delivering ~180 ft lbs of energy. That's about as much energy as the original black powder load for .32-20 Winchester, which is known to have taken virtually every game animal in North America, probably all the way up to bison.
Now, I'm not saying .32 ACP is a great hunting cartridge, but the data shows that it would certainly work. Your best bet would probably be to use FMJ to achieve adequate penetration to reach the vitals and cause lethal hemorrhaging and organ damage.
